Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 51311-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
July 2020 
 
 
People’s Republic of Bangladesh: Capacity 
Development for Bangladesh Infrastructure Finance 
Fund Limited

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT  1

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The Strengthening Bangladesh Infrastructure Finance Fund Limited (BIFFL) Project will 
support infrastructure development in Bangladesh. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
provide funds to infrastructure projects developed under the public–private partnership (PPP) 
model through BIFFL, which is a public sector financing company mandated by the Government 
of Bangladesh to support the long-term financing of PPP projects. The project will facilitate long-
term infrastructure finance, support the rollout of a PPP strategy, and strengthen the overall 
capacity of BIFFL in supporting PPP projects.   
 
2.   The  project  will  be  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  investment  in  infrastructure 
development increased.1 It will have the following outcome: PPP infrastructure projects increased, 
and new employment opportunities created. The outputs are (i) long-term debt to infrastructure 
subprojects provided and (ii) BIFFL’s institutional capacity to finance PPP infrastructure projects 
improved. The project will be financed with a $50 million loan from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
3.   Bangladesh’s economic development during 2012–2019 has been strong; gross domestic 
product grew at an average rate of 7.0% per annum during that period.2 Bangladesh is on track 
to graduate from the United Nations’ least-developed countries list in 2024.3 Rapid economic 
growth has increased the demand for energy, transportation, and urban development. However, 
infrastructure deficit remains a bottleneck and prevents the economy from reaching its full 
potential. 4  Recognizing  this  issue,  the  government  has  recently  intensified  infrastructure 
investments; since FY2016, infrastructure investments have accounted for more than 30% of the 
government budget. Nevertheless, public-sector-driven infrastructure development is constrained 
by the budget deficit, which was 5.5% in 2019, above the 5.0% ceiling level set by the government. 
Furthermore, the capacity of the public sector to implement more infrastructure development is 
also significantly stretched, as evidenced by delays and cost overruns in many projects under 
construction. It has become clear that the infrastructure investment gap cannot be addressed by 
the public sector alone, and more private sector resources must be directed to the development 
of infrastructure in Bangladesh.  
 
4.  The government has identified PPP as an important tool to mobilize more private sector 
resources into infrastructure investments. In the government’s 7th Five Year Plan, FY2016–
FY2020, PPP is expected to help bridge the infrastructure financing gap of 1.8% of gross domestic 
product on an annual basis. 
 
5. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant impact on the economy of Bangladesh. ADB 
estimates that the country’s economic growth will weaken to 4.5% in FY2020 and 1.4 million–3.7 
million workers may lose their jobs. 13 million people may fall back into poverty. With the onset of 
 
1  Government of Bangladesh, Planning Commission. 2015. The 7th Five Year Plan, FY2016–FY2020: Accelerating 
Growth, Empowering Citizen. Dhaka. 
2   ADB. 2019. Asian Development Outlook Update. Manila.  
3   Government of Bangladesh, Planning Commission. 2015. The 7th Five Year Plan, FY2016–FY2020: Accelerating 
Growth, Empowering Citizen. Dhaka. 
4  The World Economic Forum ranked Bangladesh 114th out of 141 countries in terms of infrastructure in its 2019 
Global Competitiveness Report.

2 
the pandemic, the government has also come under increasing fiscal pressures. In this context, 
PPP will take on added significance in complementing public financing to support infrastructure 
development, create jobs and spur economic growth.   
 
6.   The government has mainstreamed PPP in the economic planning process and with the 
help of ADB has developed the legal and regulatory framework to support PPP. ADB, through the 
Office of Public–Private Partnership, has also supported project preparation with transaction 
advisory services. To address long-term funding challenges of infrastructure projects, especially 
in PPP projects, the government set up BIFFL in 2011 to fund public sector infrastructure projects 
(promoted  by  line  ministries  or  local  governments),  such  as  public  roads  and  highways, 
particularly those developed by the Bangladesh PPP Authority.5  
 
7.  BIFFL is still a relatively new financial institution, with limited financial resources and 
institutional capacity. The attached transaction technical assistance (TA) will improve the capacity 
of BIFFL in screening, processing, funding, and implementing PPP infrastructure projects. During 
the project period, it is expected that two PPP projects will be reviewed and approved by 2024, 
putting BIFFL on a sustainable path to achieve its mandate to support infrastructure development.   
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
8.  Output  1:  Bangladesh  Infrastructure  Finance  Fund  Limited  business  strategy 
review and development. The TA consultants will review BIFFL’s existing corporate business 
development strategy and improve its long-term sustainability to support BIFFL’s mandated work 
in infrastructure and PPP development. This is in light of the rapid rise in the number of PPP 
projects in Bangladesh in recent years, and the rising demand for long-term, local currency debt 
funds from the market. The TA consultant will also help BIFFL identify operational gaps and refine 
the corporate strategy as required. Furthermore, the consultant will review the overall governance 
structure of BIFFL and provide assessment and recommendations for enhancement.  
 
9.  Output  2:  Comprehensive  institutional  capacity  review  and  selected  capacity 
development. The TA consultants will conduct a comprehensive review of BIFFL’s operational 
systems, including funding and treasury operations, project finance and PPP, and credit and risk 
management. Following the initial assessment, the TA scope could potentially be expanded to 
other  areas,  if  warranted,  including  accounting  and  internal  control;  corporate  information 
technology including credit risk rating models and project cycles (e.g., project identification, review, 
approval,  and  implementation  and  monitoring);  ADB  project  monitoring,  review,  and  audit; 
corporate governance; and human resources. The TA consultants will identify critical operational 
gaps and propose a capacity development strategy to improve these identified priority areas. The 
areas of implementation work will be agreed upon by BIFFL and ADB based on the available 
budget and other conditions. It is expected that at least 12 targeted training sessions (e.g., 
focused on specific functional areas) will be provided to BIFFL staff during the TA implementation 
period.  
 
10.  Output 3: A functioning environment and social safeguard unit established, and 
capacity developed. The TA consultants will help establish a functioning environment and social 
safeguard unit within BIFFL. Currently, this unit has one full-time staff member and a number of 
consultants. The unit must be strengthened under the TA to sustain BIFFL’s long-term lending 
 
5   However, because of the limited PPP pipeline, BIFFL has also been lending to non-PPP public and private sector 
infrastructure and industrial projects, similar to those funded by the Infrastructure Development Company Limited. 
The proposed project is designed to bring BIFFL back to its mandate of lending to support PPP development.

3 
operations to PPP projects. The subproject screening process will initially be limited to ADB-
funded subprojects, with training on ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and the developed 
environmental and social management system, including subproject assessment, clearance, and 
the monitoring and review process. Over the course of the project, it is expected that these 
international best practices will be gradually adopted by BIFFL to cover more projects and 
eventually become the institutional policy.   
 
11.  Output 4: Bangladesh Infrastructure Finance Fund Limited’s project administration 
and implementation capacities improved. The proposed ADB project and the attached TA are 
the first such assistances to BIFFL. Therefore, ADB needs to ensure that BIFFL has the necessary 
capacity to (i) identify and screen PPP pipeline subprojects, (ii) prepare and consolidate required 
subproject  documents  (e.g.,  feasibility  study,  environment  and  social  impact  assessment, 
financial and economic analysis, credit review and pricing notes, subloan agreement, and other 
legal contracts and agreements), (iii) conduct environment and social safeguard (involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples) reviews and clearances, (iv) assess its funding needs and 
determine its drawdown schedule, (v) choose the appropriate disbursement methods and prepare 
contract awards and disbursement projections, (vi) conduct economic and financial analysis of 
the PPP projects, and (vii) conduct periodic project reviews and prepare audit and compliance 
reports. The TA will help BIFFL meet the project administration requirements outlined in the 
project administration manual. 
 
12.  The major TA outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1. 
 
Table 1: Summary of Major Outputs and Activities

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $650,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Financial Sector Development Partnership Special Fund.6 BIFFL will provide counterpart support 
in the form of counterpart staff and in-kind contributions. Disbursement will follow ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Finance Division of the Ministry of Finance will be the 
executing agency. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants, and procure potential 
goods, e.g., computer software or network system hardware, following the ADB Procurement 
Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the  associated  project  administration 
instructions/TA Staff Instructions. The TA will be implemented over a 3-year period: 2020–2023. 
The capacity development is designed as a long-term program to improve sustainability.  
 
15.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2. 
 
Table 2: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects   Arrangements

Executing agency  Finance Division, Ministry of Finance

contracts

arrangement upon TA completion  rating models and office equipment shall be retained by BIFFL. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, BIFFL = Bangladesh Infrastructure Finance Fund Limited, QCBS = quality- and cost-
based selection, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: ADB estimates. 
 
16.  Consulting services. The TA will require 27 person-months of consulting services (12 
international and 15 national) in the areas of (i) management strategy; (ii) project finance and 
PPP, treasury operations, and risk management; and (iii) environment and social safeguards 
(Table 3). The consultants will be engaged by ADB through quality- and cost-based selection 
(with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10), using a simplified technical proposal in accordance with the 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time). The type of contract will be output 
based. International consultants will be recruited on a firm basis and the national consultants will 
be  recruited  on  an  individual  basis.  The  TA-financed  equipment  will  be  procured  by  the 
implementing agency following ADB’s Procurement Policy and Procurement Regulations for ADB 
 
6  Established by the Asian Development Bank. Financing partner: the Government of Luxembourg.

5 
Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference for consulting services 
are in Appendix 2.
